title.narrative: The ecosystem response to urban transformation: the impact of rapid urbanisation on the social demographics of ecologically-significant insect species

description.narrative: Landscapes across the world are undergoing rapid urbanisation. We will investigate the role of urban living in the life of an ecologically prominent social insect, wasps of the genus Polistes in Brazil. Do urbanised landscapes host higher densities of colonies? Does life in artificial environments recalibrate the demographics of social species? Does this have implications for social behaviour? Is an urbanised world a new ecological context to which social behaviour must adapt? Are ancestral evolutionary strategies helped or hindered by the transition to urbanisation? We will address fascinating questions such as these through thorough behavioural analyses of Brazil's polistine wasps, using a host of cutting-edge technologies - including advanced sociogenomics (the study of social behaviour and the genome) and intricate radio-tagging of wasps in the wild.

capital-spend.percentage: 1. To understand how urban transformations driven by Brazil's developing economy are changing the demographics, habitat use, and behaviour of ecologically prominent species 2. To comprehend the role of social insect demographics in ecosystems reacting to urbanisation, in the light of the global threat posed by destructive and invasive 'supercolonies' generated by human development 3. Capacity-building and knowledge transfer in the use of world-leading ecological technologies 4. Generate primary data on an overlooked - but ecologically important - aspect of Brazilian biodiversity and provider of key ecosystem services 5. Generate transferable genomics-level insight into resilience and adaptation to rapidly-changing landscapes 6. Facilitate Brazilian transition from traditional behavioural ecology to an integrated approach spanning all levels of biological organisation (from genes to ecosystems)
